description:
Adlercreutzia murintestinalis is a species of bacteria that belongs to the Firmicutes phylum. It was first isolated from the intestinal tract of mice. 

Adlercreutzia murintestinalis is an anaerobic, non-spore-forming, gram-positive bacterium. It is a member of the Clostridiaceae family and the Adlercreutzia genus. 

This species is characterized by its ability to ferment various carbohydrates, producing short-chain fatty acids as end-products. It is believed to play a role in the gut microbiome of mice and potentially other rodents.

Genome analysis has revealed that Adlercreutzia murintestinalis possesses genes involved in the metabolism of complex polysaccharides, suggesting it may contribute to the breakdown and utilization of dietary fiber in the host's intestinal tract.

Further research is needed to fully understand the ecological functions and interactions of Adlercreutzia murintestinalis within the gut microbiome, as well as its potential implications for host health and physiology.
